description: From Middle English rebellioun, rebellion, from Old French rebellion, from Latin rebellio. Also see -ion.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Armed resistance to an established government or ruler.
examples: The government is doing its best to stop rebellion in the country.

entries.meaning: (countable) Defiance of authority or control; the act of rebelling.
examples: Having a tattoo was Mathilda's personal rebellion against her parents.

entries.meaning: (countable) An organized, forceful subversion of the law of the land in an attempt to replace it with another form of government.
examples: The army general led a successful rebellion and became president of the country.
